properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Evacuation Of Hamlet Of Brule In Yellowhead County, Alberta Due To Gas Line Break
properties.Summary:
Description: All residents of Brule in Yellowhead County are being evacuated by the municipality. There is an event that has disrupted natural gas supply. Residents who are being evacuated or Brule residents already out of the evacuation area should call the Evacuation Information line at 1-833-334-4630 or go to the Doctor Duncan Murray Centre in Hinton for evacuation registration inquiries.
Expires: 2019-12-20T10:32:09-07:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Yellowhead County, 2019-12-13T10:30:11-07:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-6150
Area: Yellowhead County
properties.Author: Yellowhead County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Higher amounts possible over the Long Range Mountains. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except locally 110 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday morning. Remarks: After a brief period of snow or freezing rain Saturday evening, rain at times heavy will follow for the remainder of the night until tapering to showers Sunday morning. Strong southeasterly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rain, leading to significant snow melt and run off. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T06:18:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T14:19:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3495754779.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain with accumulations of 2 to 4 millimetres of icing are expected Friday overnight and Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A general snowfall ending this morning. An Alberta clipper type weather system has spread a large area of snow across parts of Northeastern Ontario. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected in most areas by the time the snow tapers off to a few flurries by this morning. Motorists should expect poor winter driving conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T17:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T10:19:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1201713601.2019
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Espanola - Killarney
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Although there will be moderation of extreme windchill values during the day, extreme windchill values in the -45 to -50 range will come back tonight and persist through the weekend and into next week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:15:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T16:16:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2687031651.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm grip on far Northern Ontario. Wind chill values have moderated a little today but extreme cold wind chills near minus 45 are expected to return again tonight into Saturday morning. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:15:28-00:00

Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible Saturday into Saturday night. A developing east coast storm will bring heavy snow and the risk of freezing rain to the area Friday night into early Saturday morning. Any freezing rain is not expected to last long, but will transition over to snow during the day Saturday. The snow will then continue, heavy at times, into Saturday night with significant accumulations possible by Sunday morning. The heavy snow in combination with strong, gusty winds and falling temperatures will result in difficult travel conditions Saturday night. People are advised to monitor future Environment Canada forecasts for additional information. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T08:16:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T16:17:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4140584654.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values remain near -50 this morning for communities near Great Slave Lake. Values are expected to moderate during the day; however they are forecast to approach -50 again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 60 to 100 mm. Highest amounts inland. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except 120 in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. Remarks: Rain will be heavy at times, and will occur in conjunction with very mild temperatures. Any existing snow cover will melt quickly and contribute to an elevated risk of flooding, especially near rivers or creeks and in low lying areas. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop with the arrival of the rain on Saturday evening and shift to strong southwesterly on Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T06:17:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T14:18:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3096229198.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Freezing precipitation is also possible over some areas. Total snowfall: 20 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Locations: western Labrador. Time span: Saturday night until Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Saturday night and will likely become heavy at times. Over some areas, especially from Churchill Falls eastward, the snow may change to ice pellets or freezing rain on Sunday, but will transition back to snow Sunday night. Strong northwesterly winds are also expected to develop Sunday night, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T06:35:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T14:36:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0729428097.2019
Area: Churchill Valley, Churchill Falls and vicinity, Labrador City and Wabush
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold arctic airmass is expected to remain in place throughout the remainder of this week and into mid next week. Wind chill values will moderate for most regions during the day, then once again fall into the minus 45 to 50 range overnight for the next several days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Risk of freezing rain Friday night into Saturday morning. An approaching east coast storm will bring the risk of freezing rain to the area Friday night into Saturday morning. Any freezing rain will transition over the rain during the day Saturday. However, as the system moves away from the area Saturday night, rain will transition back to snow. A quick few centimetres of accumulation is expected in combination with strong gusty winds and colder temperatures. People are advised to monitor future Environment Canada forecasts for additional information. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: Nain to Hopedale. Time span: early Sunday morning until Monday afternoon. Remarks: A major winter storm is expected to impact northern Labrador late this weekend into early next week. A combination of heavy snowfall and strong winds will result in poor visibility in blowing snow. Anyone planning weather sensitive activities is advised to plan ahead. Travel is expected to become difficult as a result of these conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall through the weekend 20 to 40 centimetres of snow are expected from Saturday to Sunday. A low pressure system from the Southern United States will intensify before reaching the province of Quebec on Saturday. An area of heavy snow will develop north of the track. Quickly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain, freezing rain, snow and wind for this weekend. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm over northernmost regions. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Higher amounts possible along the Fundy coast. Maximum wind gusts: easterly becoming southerly with gusts between 50 to 80 km/h. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday morning through Saturday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin early Saturday over northern regions, and then transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain towards evening. Over central regions, some freezing rain is likely in the morning as temperatures slowly climb above the freezing mark. Over southern regions, rain will prevail for most of the day as strong southerly winds quickly push temperatures well above the freezing mark, leading to significant snow melt and run off. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-14T06:41:52-00:00
